Title: the graduation transmission

Raj: It’s, like, the best one they make, I just can’t get it to work.
It streams HD video straight to your phone while it’s flying.
Look, the problem with commencement speeches is that they’re boring. Ooh, do you own a T-shirt cannon?
I don’t know. Why do I own one?
Mm. Hello, Daddy. What’s up?
Very well, thank you.
If you could feel how soft my skin is, you wouldn’t have to ask.
Oh, you’re where that bill goes.
No, Daddy, no. There are lots of other ways to teach me responsibility. I know, you can give me an egg and make me take care of it for a week.

But, Daddy, I, I miss my family so much, and with you and Mummy getting a divorce, I feel sad and empty. Buying a little toy every now and then helps me fill that void. So while I can’t hug you every day, flying that helicopter…
Just to be clear, financially or mid-sentence?
Hey, guys.
I have to return the helicopter. My father… What did you do?
I don’t freaking believe this.
No, you have to put this back together right now, so I can return it.
What?
Howard, my father cut me off. I have to get my money back for this.
Okay. Okay, you’re right. It’s time for me to step up and take responsibility for my life. Be a man. (On phone) Hello, Mummy.
Well, I’ve been thinking about you. How are you doing? Are you happy, Mummy?

Well, I like to think I take mostly after you. Anyway, speaking of Daddy, I had a very strange conversation with him. He said he couldn’t afford to send me money any more because of his active social life.
Well, let’s not talk about him or whatever shenanigans he may or may not be up to. Let’s talk about you.
All I know, Mummy, is that he’s a single wealthy doctor, and now, for some reason, there’s no money for your little boy.
Thank you, Mummy, I love you. Helicopters for everybody.
What’s the first one?
You guys don’t have to go to the trouble. I’m back in the money now, I can just buy another helicopter.
Not cool.
What a baby.
Check.
It’s my father, you jerks. Hello, Daddy.
Nothing. I was just calling to check in, make sure she’s doing okay.
Really? I don’t know where she’d get an idea like that. You know Mummy and her crazy imagination I’m so lucky I take after you.
Well, I try to. I certainly wouldn’t be a scientist if you hadn’t been my role model. (Re-entering apartment) Who wants to go to Vegas in a real helicopter?
How’d you do that?
Howard: I’ll figure it out.
Nice. Where were you when I was single?
Why would he own a T-shirt cannon?
Okay, the WiFi extender is on, the camera’s on, they’re both on the same network. We should be getting an image.
Maybe we should recalibrate it.
Step one, rapidly flip the calibration switch from the fully up to the fully down positions for at least ten times.
Yeah.
Sheldon.
Just flip the switch until the lights on the drone change to solid yellow.
Now I rotate it horizontally on its centre axis until the lights turn green.
It means the calibration failed. We have to start over.
No red and yellow, no red and yellow.
It’s green.
Okay, now all I have to do is rotate it vertically until the lights turn off.
Oh. All right, playtime’s over. Let’s open this baby up.
Sheldon, I have a master’s degree in engineering. I wipe my bottom with warranties. Except for AppleCare. That pays for itself in the long run.
Boy, oh, boy, that’s a lot of pieces.
Yes, of course.
Well, I, how familiar are you with miniaturized integrated logic circuits?
That right there is a miniaturized integrated logic circuit.
I’m an MIT-trained engineer. I’ve built components for the space station.
It worked fine, it just wasn’t designed for Russian cosmonauts and their potato-based diet.
Hey.
Relax, it’ll be fine.
Calm down.
Okay, I think I’ve narrowed it down to a faulty pin on the onboard communication chip.
One toy at a time.
Suicide.
Thank you.
It’s not about the money. It’s about solving a problem. It’s why I became an engineer. It’s what I like to do, it’s what I’m trained to do. It’s who I am.
Hey.
There’s two kinds of people in this world, those who call tech support, and those who make fun of the people who call tech support.
Ha-ha.
All right, the power supply is reconnected. I think we’re back in business. Let’s just run a few tests before we take it outside. Sheldon, we got WiFi?
GPS?
Battery charged?
All right. All systems go. In five…
Give me the number. Probably wind up talking to some foreign guy who’s reading from the same manual I have. (Raj’s phone rings)

What happened to me? When did I become an old man baffled by modern technology? Next thing you know, I’ll be hitching my pants up to my armpits and complaining about the awful music the kids are listening to.
Hang on, hang on. It’s working. I did it.
No idea, but I did it.
Well, I’m not flying it.
I don’t know. Must be getting a WiFi signal from somewhere else.
Leonard: Okay, we should leave in about an hour. You all packed?
Nope. It’s pretty exciting.
How would I be blinded?
I’ll take my chances.
Mm, I thought it’d be fun to show her my old stomping grounds. I even know the exact spot where they used to stomp me.
How’d you get ready so fast?
Why did you need a belt?
It gets a bad rap from shows like Jersey Shore and Real Housewives.
No, it’s like that. Well, I’m excited to show you around.
Yes. We’ll also have time to put my junk in a garlic press, but I’m not doing that either. (Receives text) Uh-oh. I just got an alert. Our flight’s been cancelled.
Yeah, looks like there’s a big storm all up the East Coast.
I don’t think so.
I guess not.
Yeah. I worked hard on that speech, too.
Oh, thank you, but I’m okay.
Greetings, distinguished cheerleaders.
Hey, where’d you go?
Really? Sex last night, pancakes this morning, am I dying?
A cap and gown? Why do I need a cap and gown?
What are you talking about?
Really? That’s amazing. And you gave me the robes to give it in. Thank you.
Short and sexy, that’s my wheelhouse.
I don’t think this is gonna work.
A, surprised you know that. B, I wanted to look like a sexy graduate for you.
Thank you.
Well, I’m gonna go put on some pants just in case. But I have to say, this is very freeing.
Oh. Done and done.
They’re graduating.

My point is, while you’re spending all this time on your own, building computers or practicing your cello, what you’re really doing is becoming interesting. And when people finally do notice you, they’re gonna find someone a lot cooler than they thought. And for those of you who were popular in high school, it’s over, sorry. Thank you and congratulations.
So you really think they liked it?
Penny: Uh, yeah, I just need to throw in a few last minute things, you know, makeup, underwear, clothes.
Oh, I pack light. Once, I got through an entire spring break with nothing but a long T-shirt and a belt.
It’s called an evening look. I’ve never been to New Jersey before.
So it’s not really like that?
You think we’ll have time to visit your mom over there?
What?
Well, can we get on another airline?
So, that’s it? We’re not going?
Well, that sucks.
Oh. You could tell it to me.
Are you sure? I could pretend I’m a high school cheerleader who can’t control herself around esteemed alumni.
Ooh.
Hi.
I got you a little something to cheer you up.
Just open it.
Because you are giving your commencement speech.
I called your old high school and convinced them to let you give your speech over Skype.
Yeah, now about those, uh, they came from a costume shop, and all they had left was sexy graduate, so they might be a little short.
Yeah.
What’s taking so long?
Just let me see. Sweetie, you know you’re supposed to wear clothes underneath a graduation gown.
Oh. Well, you do.
Yeah. You’re gonna be on Skype, they’re not gonna see your legs.
Add a belt and I’ll take you some place nice.
Oh. Hello. I, I didn’t know he was gonna point it at me, so, don’t do drugs and stay in school.
Okay, bye.
I’ll, I’ll tell you later.
Oh, sweetie, it was the best speech I…
Sheldon: If your bathroom floor counts as a carry-on, you’re packed.
Aren’t you afraid of being blinded?
At the end of the ceremony, all the students throw those pointy hats in the air. It’s all pomp and circumstance until someone loses an eye.
Fine. I wonder if they make I told you so cards in braille.
And a pointy hat sticking out of your eyeball.
All I see is a black screen. And my own reflection. I look sad.
All right.
It actually says at least?
Why would they say at least? Is it ten toggles? Is it a hundred toggles? You know? Is it a thousand toggles? Ten thousand toggles? A hundred thousand toggles?
You see where I’m going with this.

All right, that seems simple enough. Initiating calibration sequence. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten. Well, I suppose ten is technically at least ten. But they’re still getting at least one angry letter.
Initiating rotation sequence. Don’t look at me, initiate. What does red and yellow mean?
Oh. Very well. Re-initiating calibration sequence. One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten… eleven. It’s a good thing I didn’t send that letter.
Yay.
We did it. Oh, if it’s this much fun to rotate, imagine when we fly it.
Oh, no.
Won’t that void the warranty?
You know what they all do, right?
What about this one?
Not very.
So, can you get it working?
I thought the zero-gravity toilet didn’t work.
Hello.
Well, don’t worry. He went to MIT. He can solve any problem, as long as it doesn’t originate in a Russian man’s colon.
You can’t return it. Howard wiped his bottom with the warranty.
I think metaphorically. But he was in the bathroom for a while.
Very impressive. You know, when you’re done with that, can you look at this? It doesn’t make smoke anymore.
Mm. Sorry. Ah, maybe it’s for the best. I hear locomotive smoke is the second leading cause of death among train aficionados.
Wrong. Obesity.
Oh, look at you, the little engineer that could.
Whoa.
You call tech support.
Check.
Check.
That’s what my train used to do.
It is awful, isn’t it? Listen to that noise.
Then who is?
Initiate landing sequence. Initiate landing sequence. Hey, the camera’s working. Oh, look, it’s me.
Yes, it’s a robot uprising. Call the police.
Don’t worry, everyone in here is safe.
Amy: Leonard, have you ever given a high school commencement speech before?
I think it’s really nice that you’re sharing this experience with Penny.
With a beautiful girl on your arm.
Bernadette: Well, now you get to go back as a successful scientist.
I have the tool you wanted.
Why don’t you just call tech support?
I call tech support all the time.
Four hours of our lives gone? Check.
Maybe you shouldn’t be flying it inside.
Dr Koothrapalli: Not much, just wanted to see how my son’s doing.
Are you still dating that dermatologist?
Oh, and there’s something else I wanted to ask you. Why did you spend a month’s rent on a toy helicopter?!
I’m tired of indulging your foolish lifestyle. It’s time you learned responsibility. And the only way to teach you that is to cut off your allowance.
No, my mind is made up. Starting now, you’re on your own.
What did you say to your mother?
Well, after talking to you, she seems to think I’m some sort of playboy.
You think you take after me?
Mrs Koothrapalli: Hello, Rajesh. What a nice surprise.
Such a sweet boy for asking. Can’t believe you come from the poison seed of your father.
What does that mean, active social life?
Rajesh, is your father seeing someone?
Well, however much money your father was giving you, I’ll give you more.
Headmaster: And now, for our commencement address, one of our most distinguished alumni, noted Caltech physicist Dr. Leonard Hofstadter.
Leonard (on screen): Members of the faculty, students, I’m excited to speak to you today. I can’t help but remember the last time I was in this auditorium. Two guys from the lacrosse team played keep-away with my asthma inhaler. But enough about my ten-year reunion. I’d also like to take a moment to thank my beautiful fiancée for to helping make this speech possible, even though weather nearly prevented it.

It was L. Frank Baum who said no thief, however skillful, can rob one of knowledge, and that is why knowledge is the best and safest treasure, wow, I’m boring myself. Sorry, I can’t see any of your faces right now, but I bet they look like this. Uh, you know, I, I wrote an entire speech to say how high school prepares you and what a wonderful place it is, but I hated it. Maybe high school’s great if you look like this, but I didn’t even feel like I existed at that school. And now that I think about it, I bet a lot of you feel the same way. So, for the remainder of my speech, this is for the invisible kids. Uh, maybe you never fit in. Or maybe you’re the smallest kid in the school, or the heaviest or the weirdest. Maybe you’re graduating and you still haven’t had your first kiss. By the way, 19, and Geraldine Coco, wherever you are, thank you. Maybe you don’t have any friends. And guess what? That’s okay. While all the popular kids are off doing whatever, I don’t know what they were doing ’cause I was never there.
Tech Support Voice: Your call is important to us. All our technicians are busy helping other customers. Please stay on the line and someone will be with you shortly.
Tech Support Guy: Tech Support, can I help you?
